info.name: Monk
info.description: The Monk class from the Player’s Handbook.
info.author: Wizards of the Coast

description.p: Her fists a blur as they deflect an incoming hail of arrows, a young woman springs over a barricade and throws herself into the massed ranks of hobgoblins on the other side. She whirls among them, knocking their blows aside and sending them reeling, until at last she stands alone.
Taking a deep breath, a man covered in tattoos settles into a battle stance. As the first charging orcs reach him, he exhales and a blast of fire roars from his mouth, engulfing his foes.

Moving with the silence of the night, a black-clad woman steps into a shadow beneath an arch and emerges from another inky shadow on a balcony a stone’s throw away. She slides her blade free of its clothwrapped scabbard and peers through the open window at the tyrant prince, so vulnerable in the grip of sleep.

Whatever their discipline, monks are united in their ability to harness the energy that flows in their bodies. Whether channeled as a striking display of combat prowess or a subtler focus of defensive ability and speed, this energy infuses all that a monk does.

Monks make careful study of a magical energy that most monastic traditions call essence. This energy is an element of the magic that suffuses the world—specifically, the element that flows through living bodies. Monks harness this power within themselves to create magical effects and exceed their bodies’ physical capabilities, and some of their special attacks can hinder the flow of essence in their opponents. Using this energy, monks channel uncanny speed and strength into their unarmed strikes. As they gain experience, their martial training and their mastery of essence gives them more power over their bodies and the bodies of their foes.

Small walled cloisters dot the landscapes of the worlds of D&D, tiny refuges from the flow of ordinary life, where time seems to stand still. The monks who live there seek personal perfection through contemplation and rigorous training. Many entered the monastery as children, sent to live there when their parents died, when food couldn’t be found to support them, or in return for some kindness that the monks had performed for their families.

Some monks live entirely apart from the surrounding population, secluded from anything that might impede their spiritual progress. Others are sworn to isolation, emerging only to serve as spies or assassins at the command of their leader, a noble patron, or some other mortal or divine power.

The majority of monks don’t shun their neighbors, making frequent visits to nearby towns or villages and exchanging their service for food and other goods. As versatile warriors, monks often end up protecting their neighbors from monsters or tyrants.

For a monk, becoming an adventurer means leaving a structured, communal lifestyle to become a wanderer. This can be a harsh transition, and monks don’t undertake it lightly. Those who leave their cloisters take their work seriously, approaching their adventures as personal tests of their physical and spiritual growth. As a rule, monks care little for material wealth and are driven by a desire to accomplish a greater mission than merely slaying monsters and plundering their treasure.

As you make your monk character, think about your connection to the monastery where you learned your skills and spent your formative years. Were you an orphan or a child left on the monastery’s threshold? Did your parents promise you to the monastery in gratitude for a service performed by the monks? Did you enter this secluded life to hide from a crime you committed? Or did you choose the monastic life for yourself?

Consider why you left. Did the head of your monastery choose you for a particularly important mission beyond the cloister? Perhaps you were cast out because of some violation of the community’s rules. Did you dread leaving, or were you happy to go? Is there something you hope to accomplish outside the monastery? Are you eager to return to your home?
As a result of the structured life of a monastic community and the discipline required to harness essence, monks are almost always lawful in alignment.
You can make a monk quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom. Second, choose the hermit background.
As a monk, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d8 per monk level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per monk level after 1st
Armor: None
Weapons: Simple weapons, shortswords
Tools: Choose one type of artisan’s tools or one musical instrument
Saving Throws: Strength, Dexterity
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, History, Insight, Religion, and Stealth

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a shortsword or (b) any simple weapon
(a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack
10 darts

tr.td: Deflect Energy, Tongue of the Sun and Moon
Ability Score Improvement, Wholeness of Self

sheet.description: A master of martial arts, harnessing the power of the body in pursuit of physical and spiritual perfection.

setters.set: A master of martial arts, harnessing the power of the body in pursuit of physical and spiritual perfection.

description.p: Beginning at 1st level, while you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

sheet.description: While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals {{ac:unarmored defense monk}}.

description.p: At 1st level, your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use unarmed strikes and monk weapons, which are shortswords and any simple melee weapons that don’t have the two-handed or heavy property.
You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only monk weapons and you aren’t wearing armor or wielding a shield:

ul.li: Martial Arts Die. You can roll a d4 in place of the normal damage of your unarmed strike or monk weapon. This Martial Arts die changes as you gain monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table.

Dextrous Attacks. You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes and monk weapons. In addition, when you choose the Grapple or Shove option, you can use your Dexterity modifier instead of Strength to determine the saving throw DC.
Bonus Unarmed Strike. You can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.

sheet.description: Your unarmed strikes do 1d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{martial arts:damage}} damage. Monk weapon attacks can also roll this damage instead of their normal weapon damage. You can use your Dexterity modifier to determine the saving throw DC for Grapple and Shove attacks. You can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, your training allows you to harness the mystic energy of essence. Your access to this energy is represented by a number of essence points. Your monk level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Essence Points column of the Monk table.

You can spend these points to fuel various essence features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind. You learn more essence features as you gain levels in this class.

When you spend a essence point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you draw all of your expended essence back into yourself. You must spend at least 10 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your essence points.
Some of your essence features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature’s effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

center.p: Essence save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

description.p: You can spend 1 essence point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action.
You can spend 1 essence point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn, and you gain temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier.
You can spend 1 essence point to take both the Disengage and Dash actions as a single bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

sheet.description: You have {{essence:points}} essence points. The save DC for your essence features is {{essence:dc}}.

description.p: You can spend 1 essence point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 essence point to make two unarmed strikes.
You can spend 1 essence point to make three unarmed strikes.

description.p: You can spend 1 essence point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn and gain temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 essence point to take the Dodge action and gain {{wisdom:modifier}} temporary hit points.

You can spend 1 essence point to take the Dodge action and gain 1d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{wisdom:modifier}} temporary hit points. You roll an additional Martial Arts die for your Deflect Attacks feature until the start of your next turn.

description.p: You can spend 1 essence point to take both the Disengage and Dash actions as a single bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 essence point to take both the Disengage and Dash actions on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

You can spend 1 essence point to take both the Disengage or Dash action on your turn, and your jump distance is limited only by your speed. In addition, you can choose up to {{monk:wind_creatures}} willing creatures within 5 feet of you that are Large size or smaller and do not have their movement speed reduced to 0. These creatures will move with you until the end of your turn and will not provoke opportunity attacks for this movement.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain monk levels, as shown in the Monk table.
At 9th level, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

sheet.description: Your speed increases by {{monk:unarmored movement}} feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield.

Your speed increases by {{monk:unarmored movement}} feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. You gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

description.p: When you reach 3rd level, you commit yourself to a monastic tradition, such as the Way of the Open Hand. Your tradition grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

Starting at 3rd level, you can spend 1 essence and use your reaction to deflect an attack made against you that deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by the roll of Martial Arts dice + your monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0, you can redirect the attack to a creature other than yourself. Choose a creature within 5 feet if the attack was a melee attack, or 60 feet if the attack was a ranged attack. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take half of the deflected attack's original damage.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 essence to deflect an attack made against you that deals bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 2d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{monk:deflect attacks bonus}}. If you reduce the damage to 0, you can redirect the attack to a creature other than yourself. Choose a creature within 5 feet if the attack was a melee attack, or 60 feet if the attack was a ranged attack. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC {{deflect:dc}}) or take half of the attack's original damage.

You can spend 1 essence to deflect an attack made against you that deals any type damage other than psychic. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 2d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{monk:deflect attacks bonus}}. If you reduce the damage to 0, you can redirect the attack to a creature other than yourself. Choose a creature within 5 feet if the attack was a melee attack, or 60 feet if the attack was a ranged attack. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC {{deflect:dc}}) or take half of the attack's original damage.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, and 20th level, you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, if your DM allows it, you can take one feat of your choice instead.
Beginning at 4th level, you can use your reaction when you fall to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your monk level.

sheet.description: Reduce any falling damage you take by {{monk:slowfall}}.

description.p: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Starting at 5th level, you can interfere with the flow of essence in an opponent’s body. Once per turn, when you hit another creature with a monk weapon or unarmed strike, you can spend 2 essence points to attempt a stunning strike. The target must make on a Constitution saving throw, and has advantage on the roll if it suffered from the stunned condition within the last 10 minutes. On a failed save, the target is stunned until the start of your next turn. On a successful save, the target takes force damage equal to the roll of a Martial Arts Die plus your Wisdom ability modifier.

sheet.description: Once per turn, when you hit another creature with a monk weapon or unarmed strike, you can spend 2 essence points to attempt a stunning strike. The target makes a Constitution saving throw (DC {{stun:dc}}) with advantage if it suffered from the stunned condition within the last 10 minutes. On a failed save the target is stunned until the start of your next turn. On a succesful save it suffers 1d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{monk:stun bonus}} force damage.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

sheet.description: Your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

description.p: At 7th level, your instinctive agility lets you dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a blue dragon’s lightning breath or a fireball spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

sheet.description: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, at the end of each of your turns you can choose to end either the charmed or frightened condition on yourself.

sheet.description: You can end either the charmed or frightened condition on yourself at the end of each of your turns.

description.p: At 10th level, your mastery of the essence flowing through you makes you immune to disease and poison.

sheet.description: You are immune to disease and poison.

description.p: At 10th level, you learn to call upon deeper reserves of essence in times of need. When you roll Initiative and have 3 essence points or fewer, you regain essence points until you have 4.

sheet.description: When you roll Initiative and have 3 essence points or fewer, you regain essence points until you have 4.

element.name: Tongue of the Sun and Moon

description.p: Starting at 13th level, you learn to touch the essence of other minds so that you understand all spoken languages. Moreover, any creature that can understand a language can understand what you say.

sheet.description: You understand all spoken languages, and be understood by any creature that understands a language.

description.p: You can now use your Deflect Attacks feature against attacks that deal any type of damage, with the exception of psychic damage.
Beginning at 17th level, your mastery of essence grants you proficiency in all saving throws.
Additionally, whenever you make a saving throw and fail, you can spend 1 essence point to reroll it and take the second result.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 essence point to reroll a failed saving throw and take that result.

description.p: At 15th level, your essence sustains you so that you suffer none of the frailty of old age, and you can’t be aged magically. You can still die of old age, but your lifespan is doubled. In addition, you no longer need food or water.

sheet.description: You suffer no negative effects from aging, age at half the normal rate, can’t be aged magically, and no longer need food or water.

description.p: At 14th level, your mind and spirit function in perfect harmony. Whenever you spend a hit die for healing, you also regain 1 essence point. Whenever you do so as part of a short rest, you instead heal the maximum value of your Martial Arts Die plus your Wisdom ability modifier in additional hit points.

sheet.description: Whenever you spend a hit die for healing, you also regain 1 essence point. Whenever you do so as part of a short rest, you instead heal {{monk:heal bonus}} additional hit points.

description.p: At 15th level, your training has pushed your martial arts to the very pinnacle of competence. Your Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind gain the following benefits:

ul.li: Flurry of Blows. When you use Flurry of Blows you can make three unarmed strikes instead of two.

Patient Defense. When you use Patient Defense you add the roll of a Martial Arts Die to your Wisdom modifier to determine the temporary hit points gained. In addition, you roll an additional Martial Arts die for your Deflect Attacks feature until the start of your next turn.

Step of the Wind. When you use Step of the Wind your jump distance is limited only by your movement speed. In addition, you can choose a number creatures within 5 feet of you equal to your Wisdom modifier. They must be willing, Large size or smaller, and not have their movement speed reduced to 0. These creatures will move with you until the end of your turn and will not provoke opportunity attacks for this movement.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, you can use your action to spend 6 essence points to become invisible for 1 minute. During that time, you also have resistance to all damage except force and psychic damage.
Additionally, you can spend 8 essence points to cast the astral projection spell, without needing material components. When you do so, you can’t take any other creatures with you.

sheet.description: You can spend 6 essence points to become invisible for 1 minute. During that time, you also have resistance to all damage except force and psychic damage. You can spend 8 essence points to cast the astral projection spell, without needing material components. When you do so, you can’t take any other creatures with you.

description.p: At 20th level, you have honed your body and mind to new heights. Your Dexterity and Wisdom scores increase by 4, and your maximum for those scores is now 24.

sheet.description: Your Dexterity and Wisdom scores increase by 4, and your maximum for those scores is now 24.

description.p: Monks of the Way of the Open Hand are the ultimate masters of martial arts combat, whether armed or unarmed. They learn techniques to push and trip their opponents, manipulate essence to heal damage to their bodies, and practice advanced meditation that can protect them from harm.

sheet.description: The ultimate masters of martial arts combat, whether armed or unarmed.

description.p: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can manipulate your enemy’s essence when you harness your own. Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows, you can impose one of the following effects on that target:

ul.li: It must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be knocked prone.
It must make a Strength saving throw. If it fails, you can push it up to 15 feet away from you.
It can’t take reactions until the end of your next turn.

sheet.description: Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows, you can impose one of the following effects on that target: knock prone DEX Save, Push 15 feet STR Save, It can’t take reactions until the end of your next turn.

description.p: At 6th level, you gain the ability to heal yourself. As an action, you can enter a short but deep trance, effectively stunning yourself until the start of your next turn. At this point, you will regain hit points equal to five times your Monk level. You must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.

sheet.description: Become stunned until the start of your next turn, then regain {{monk:wholeness of body}} hit points.

description.p: Beginning at 11th level, you can enter a special meditation that surrounds you with an aura of peace. At the end of a long rest, you gain the effect of a sanctuary spell that lasts until the start of your next long rest (the spell can end early as normal). The saving throw DC for the spell equals 8 + your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you gain the effect of a sanctuary spell that lasts until the start of your next long rest (the spell can end early as normal). The saving throw DC for the spell equals {{tranquility:dc}}.

description.p: At 17th level, you gain the ability to set up lethal vibrations in someone’s body. When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 3 essence points to start these imperceptible vibrations, which last for a number of days equal to your monk level. The vibrations are harmless unless you use your action to end them. To do so, you and the target must be on the same plane of existence. When you use this action, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw. If it fails, it is reduced to 0 hit points. If it succeeds, it takes 10d10 necrotic damage.
You can have only one creature under the effect of this feature at a time. You can choose to end the vibrations harmlessly without using an action.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 3 essence points to start these imperceptible vibrations, which last for {{level:monk}} days. The vibrations are harmless unless you use your action to end them. To do so, you and the target must be on the same plane of existence. When you use this action, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw. If it fails, it is reduced to 0 hit points. If it succeeds, it takes 10d10 necrotic damage. You can have only one creature under the effect of this feature at a time. You can choose to end the vibrations harmlessly without using an action.

description.p: Monks of the Way of Shadow follow a tradition that values stealth and subterfuge. These monks might be called ninjas or shadowdancers, and they serve as spies and assassins. Sometimes the members of a ninja monastery are family members, forming a clan sworn to secrecy about their arts and missions. Other monasteries are more like thieves’ guilds, hiring out their services to nobles, rich merchants, or anyone else who can pay their fees. Regardless of their methods, the heads of these monasteries expect the unquestioning obedience of their students.

sheet.description: Monks of the Way of Shadow follow a tradition that values stealth and subterfuge.

description.p: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can use your essence to duplicate the effects of certain spells. As an action, you can spend 2 essence points to cast darkness, darkvision, pass without trace, or silence, without providing material components. Additionally, you gain the minor illusion cantrip if you don’t already know it.

sheet.description: You can spend 2 essence points to cast darkness, darkvision, pass without trace, or silence, without providing material components. Additionally, you gain the minor illusion cantrip if you don’t already know it.

description.p: At 6th level, you gain the ability to step from one shadow into another. When you are in dim light or darkness, as a bonus action you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. You then have advantage on the first melee attack you make before the end of the turn.

sheet.description: When you are in dim light or darkness, you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. You then have advantage on the first melee attack you make before the end of the turn.

description.p: By 11th level, you have learned to become one with the shadows. When you are in an area of dim light or darkness, you can use your action to become invisible. You remain invisible until you make an attack, cast a spell, or are in an area of bright light.

sheet.description: When you are in an area of dim light or darkness, you can become invisible. You remain invisible until you make an attack, cast a spell, or are in an area of bright light.

description.p: At 17th level, you can exploit a creature’s momentary distraction when it is hit by an attack. Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you is hit by an attack made by a creature other than you, you can use your reaction to make a melee attack against that creature.

sheet.description: Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you is hit by an attack made by a creature other than you, you can make a melee attack against that creature.

description.p: You follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the elements. When you focus your essence, you can align yourself with the forces of creation and bend the four elements to your will, using them as an extension of your body. Some members of this tradition dedicate themselves to a single element, but others weave the elements together.

Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their elemental powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as phoenixes, fish, plants, mountains, and cresting waves.

sheet.description: You follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the elements.

description.p: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you learn magical disciplines that harness the power of the four elements. Each discipline grants you access to a spell that requires you to spend essence points each time you cast it.

You know the Elementalism discipline and two other elemental disciplines of your choice, which are detailed in the “Elemental Disciplines” section below. You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.
Whenever you learn a new elemental discipline, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

Casting Elemental Spells. Each elemental discipline gives you access to a spell. To cast one of these spells, you spend essence points equal to its level. The spell is then cast following all the normal rules for spellcasting (see chapter 10). Certain spells can be cast at a higher level to enhance their effects, as stated in their description. To do so, spend essence points equal to the desired level of the spell, rather than its actual level. The maximum number of essence points you can spend on a single spellcasting is equal to your proficiency bonus.

p.i: For example, it would normally cost 1 essence point to cast Sweeping Cinder Strike (a 1st-level spell). However, you could instead spend 2 essence points to cast it as a 2nd-level spell, increasing its damage by one die (as stated in the spell's description). For a third-level character with a profiency bonus of +2, this is the highest level at which the spell can be cast.

description.p: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your elemental discipline spells. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a discipline spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

sheet.description: You learn elemental disciplines that grant you access to spells.

You can cast an elemental discipline spell by spending essence points equal to its level (0 for cantrips). You can spend additional essence points to cast the spell at a higher level if the spell allows for it. The maximum level at which you can cast a spell is {{proficiency}}.

description.p: You hurl an undulating, warbling mass of chaotic energy at one creature in range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 + 2d4 damage. Choose one of the d6s. The number rolled on that die determines the attack's damage type, as shown below.

If you roll the same number on any of the d6s, the chaotic energy leaps from the target to a different creature of your choice within 30 feet of it. Make a new attack roll against the new target, and make a new damage roll, which could cause the chaotic energy to leap again.

A creature can be targeted only once by each casting of this spell. Note that you must pick a new target when the spell leaps, if possible. This means you might be forced to pick a less desirable target (such as an ally!).
For this spell, only the 2d4 dice scale with your Martial Arts dice. While your Martial Arts dice are also d6s, use two pair of different colored dice to keep them apart.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, each target takes 1d4 extra damage of the type rolled for each slot level above 1st.
Starting at level 17, you can add your Wisdom modifier to one damage roll of any elemental discipline spell you cast.

sheet.description: You can add {{wisdom:modifier}} to one damage roll of any elemental discipline spell you cast.

description.p: Starting at 3rd level, the potency of your elemental spells increases with your martial arts training. When casting an elemental discipline spell, you can choose to use your Martial Arts dice instead of the dice the spell would normally use. This only changes the die type, not the number of dice. For example, Sweeping Cinder Strike normally does 4d4 damage, but if your Martial Arts Die is a d8, the spell would do 4d8 damage instead.

sheet.description: Spell damage dice scale with your Martial Arts dice.

description.p: Starting at 3rd level, yhen you spend an action casting an elemental discipline spell, you can choose for the damage of your unarmed attacks to have the same damage type as the spell (if any) until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: Attacks can have same damage type as spell cast.

description.p: You can cast Elementalism without spending essence points.

sheet.description: You can briefly control elemental forces within 30 feet of you.

description.p: You exert control over the elements, creating one of the following effects within range:

Beckon Air. You create a breeze strong enough to ripple cloth, stir dust, rustle leaves, and close open doors and shutters, all in a 5-foot cube. Doors and shutters being held open by someone or something aren’t affected.
Beckon Earth. You create a thin shroud of dust or sand that covers surfaces in a 5-foot-square area, or you cause a single word to appear in your handwriting in a patch of dirt or sand.

Beckon Fire. You create a thin cloud of harmless embers and colored, scented smoke in a 5-foot cube. You choose the color and scent, and the embers can light candles, torches, or lamps in that area. The smoke’s scent lingers for 1 minute.

Beckon Water. You create a spray of cool mist that lightly dampens creatures and objects in a 5-foot cube. Alternatively, you create 1 cup of clean water either in an open container or on a surface, and the water evaporates in 1 minute.
Sculpt Element. You cause dirt, sand, fire, smoke, mist, or water that can fit in a 1-foot cube to assume a crude shape (such as that of a creature or an object) for 1 hour.
You can spend 5 or more essence points to cast Breath of Winter.

sheet.description: You can spend 5 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You breathe a gale of freezing air. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 6d12 cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature killed by this spell becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d12 for each slot level above 5th.
You can spend 2 essence points to cast Clench of the North Wind.

sheet.description: You can spend 2 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: As you clench your fist, crushing winds envelop your target and hold them into place. Choose a humanoid that you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage and be restrained for the duration. To escape, the target can use its action to make a Strength saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target. If the target attempts to use its action for anything other than escape, it will first suffer 2d6 bludgeoning damage.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, both the initial and subsequent damage increase by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.
You can spend 4 essence points to cast Eternal Mountain Defense.

sheet.description: You can spend 4 essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You enter the stance of the implacable mountain, your skin becoming as hard as stone. Until the spell ends, you have resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
You can spend 2 essence points to cast Fangs of the Fire Snake.

sheet.description: You can spend 2 essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: Tendrils of flame stretch out from your fists and feet. You can take an Attack action as part of the action used to cast this spell. Attacks you make through the casting of this spell, as well as any other monk weapon attacks and unarmed strikes you make before the start of your next turn, deal one additional die of fire damage and have their reach increased to 15 feet.
You can spend 1 essence point to cast Fist of Four Thunders.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You gather a trembling force in your hand, then unleash it with a deafening strike. Each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 3d4 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn’t pushed. In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you by the spell’s effect, and the spell emits a thunderous boom audible out to 300 feet.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 1st.
You can spend 2 essence points to cast Fist of Unbroken Air.

sheet.description: You can spend 2 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You strike out with both hands, creating a blast of compressed air that slams into your opponent like a mighty fist. Choose a creature within 15 feet of you. That creature must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and you push the creature 20 feet away from you and knock it prone. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and you must choose to have it either be pushed back 5 feet or knocked prone.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.
You can spend 3 essence points to cast Flames of the Phoenix.

sheet.description: You can spend 3 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You leap into the air and land between your enemies in an explosion of flames. As part of the action to cast this spell, you can jump up to 30 feet horizontally or 15 feet vertically. This jump does not cost any of your movement and does not provoke opportunity attacks. It can extend a jump that was started before the casting of this spell. When you land, a wave of fire sweeps out from you in all directions. Each creature within a 20-foot radius of you, other than yourself, must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature suffers 5d8 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a succesful one. The fire spreads around corners. It ignites flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.
You cannot cast this spell if you are restrained, grappled, or your movement speed is reduced to 0 for any other reason.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 3rd.
You can spend 3 essence points to cast Mist Stance.

sheet.description: You can spend 3 essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: As you trace intricate gestures through the air, mist rises around you until finally you disappear in the mist yourself. You transform into a misty cloud for the duration of the spell, along with everything you're wearing and carrying. The spell ends if you drop to 0 hit points. While in this form, your only method of movement is a flying speed equal to your unarmored movement bonus. You can enter and occupy the space of another creature. You have resistance to nonmagical damage, and you have advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws. You can pass through small holes, narrow openings, and even mere cracks, though you treat liquids as though they were solid surfaces. You can’t fall and remain hovering in the air even when stunned or otherwise incapacitated. While in the form of a misty cloud, you can’t talk or manipulate objects, and any objects you were carrying or holding can’t be dropped, used, or otherwise interacted with. You can’t attack or cast spells.
You can spend 3 essence points to cast Ride the Wind.

sheet.description: You can spend 3 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: Wind gathers around you as you leap into the air. You gain a flying speed of 60 feet for the duration of the spell. When the spell ends, you fall if you are still aloft, unless you can stop the fall.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you increase the flying speed by 20 feet for each slot level above 3rd.
You can spend 4 essence points to cast River of Hungry Flame.

sheet.description: You can spend 4 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: As you trace your foot over the ground, a river of lava opens up at a distance from you on a solid surface within range. You can make the river up to 60 feet long, 1 foot deep, and 10 foot wide, or a ringed moat with an inner diameter of up to 30 feet, 1 foot deep, and 10 foot wide. Flames and lava spurts leap from the river up to 5 feet above ground level, and the river lasts for the duration of the spell. The area of the river is considered difficult terrain.

When the river appears, each creature within its area must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5d8 fire damage. On a successful save the creature takes only half as much damage.

A creature that enters the river's area for the first time on its turn or ends its turn there takes 5d8 fire damage. A creature can attempt to jump over the river, but will need to cross a distance of at least 20 feet and succeed at an Strength (Athletics) check to take no damage. Creatures that fail to or are unable to do so still take half of the 5d8 fire damage. Creatures that fail to jump the required 10 feet end up in the river and take full damage.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 4th.
You can spend 1 essence point to cast Sweeping Cinder Strike.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You make a sweeping kick that sends out a wave of fire. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 4d4 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 1st.
You can spend 1 essence point to cast Earth Trembling Step.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You stomp the ground, sending a tremor through the earth that unbalances nearby foes. Each creature other than you within a 10-foot radius makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d4 bludgeoning damage and is knocked prone. If the ground in that area is loose earth or stone, it becomes difficult terrain until cleared, which requires at least 1 minute.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 1st.
You can spend 1 essence point to cast Water Whip.

sheet.description: You can spend 1 or more essence points to cast this spell.

description.p: You lash out with a whip of water to pull creatures toward you. You can attack three times with the water whip, attacking either the same target or several. Make a ranged spell attack roll for each whip attack. On a hit, the target takes 1d4 bludgeoning damage and if it is Large or smaller it is pulled 5 feet towards you.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can make one additional whip attack for each slot level above 1st, up to a maximum of three additional whip attacks at 4th level.
You can spend 5 essence points to cast wall of stone.

sheet.description: You can spend 5 essence points to cast wall of stone.

description.p: Monks of the Way of the Kensei train relentlessly with their weapons, to the point where the weapon becomes an extension of the body. Founded on a mastery of sword fighting, the tradition has expanded to include many different weapons.

A kensei sees a weapon in much the same way a calligrapher or painter regards a pen or brush. Whatever the weapon, the kensei views it as a tool used to express the beauty and precision of the martial arts. That such mastery makes a kensei a peerless warrior is but a side effect of intense devotion, practice, and study.

sheet.description: Channels essence through a set of mastered weapons

description.p: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, your special martial arts training leads you to master the use of certain weapons. This path also includes instruction in the deft strokes of calligraphy or painting. You gain the following benefits.

Kensei Weapons. Choose one type of melee weapon to be your kensei weapon. It can be any type of simple or martial weapon that lacks the heavy and special properties. You gain proficiency with this weapon if you don’t already have it. Weapons of the chosen types are monk weapons for you. Many of this tradition’s features work only with your kensei weapons. When you reach 6th, 11th, and 17th level in this class, you can choose another type of weapon to be a kensei weapon for you following the criteria above.

Agile Parry. If you make an unarmed strike as part of the Attack action on your turn and are holding a kensei weapon, you can use it to defend yourself if it is a melee weapon. You gain a +2 bonus to AC until the start of your next turn, while the weapon is in your hand and you aren't incapacitated.
Way of the Brush. You gain proficiency with your choice of calligrapher's supplies or painter's supplies.

sheet.description: Your kensei weapons are monk weapons.

description.p: If you make an unarmed strike as part of the Attack action on your turn and are holding a kensei weapon, you can use it to defend yourself if it is a melee weapon. You gain a +2 bonus to AC until the start of your next turn, while the weapon is in your hand and you aren't incapacitated.

sheet.description: If you make an unarmed strike as part of the Attack action on your turn, you can use a melee kensei weapon to defend yourself. You gain a +2 bonus to AC until the start of your next turn, while the weapon is in your hand and you aren't incapacitated.

description.p: At 6th level, you extend your essence into your kensei weapons, granting you the following benefits.
Magic Kensei Weapons. Your attacks with your kensei weapons count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.
Deft Strike. Before you attack a target with a kensei weapon, you can spend 1 essence point to gain advantage on the attack roll. You can use this feature only once on each of your turns.

sheet.description: Attacks with kensei weapons are considered magical. Once per turn you can spend 1 essence point to gain advantage on an attack roll with a kensei weapon.

description.p: At 11th level, you gain the ability to augment your weapons further with your essence. As a bonus action, you can expend up to 3 essence points to grant one kensei weapon you touch a bonus to attack and damage rolls when you attack with it. The bonus equals the number of essence points you spent. This bonus lasts for 1 minute or until you use this feature again. This feature has no effect on a magic weapon that already has a bonus to attack and damage rolls.

sheet.description: Expend up to 3 essence point to grant one kensei weapon you touch a bonus to attack and damage, equal to the essence points spent, for 1 minute. (no effect on magic weapons that already have a bonus)

description.p: At 17th level, your mastery of weapons grants you extraordinary accuracy. Whenever you make an attack roll with a kensei weapon that has advantage and both rolls would result in a hit, you may add your Martial Arts damage die to the damage roll of the attack.

sheet.description: Whenever you make an attack roll with a kensei weapon that has advantage and both rolls would result in a hit, you may add your Martial Arts damage die to the damage roll of the attack.

description.p: You gain proficiency with this weapon if you don’t already have it, and it is a monk weapon for you.
